G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this court under G.L. c. 212, § 4, as this court has general jurisdiction over tort claims, and the amount in controversy exceeds the statutory minimum threshold for Superior Court jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this court under G.L. c. 223, § 2, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and operator of the Bargain Home Goods store, owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect store patrons from hazardous conditions that could foreseeably result in injuries.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The case expressly states the general duty of a party who controls business premises toward its patrons: to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe and to warn of dangers not likely to be known to them but known or knowable to the defendant. While Oliveri involves a subway station rather than a retail store, the articulated rule is a general business‑premises duty that applies equally to store owners/operators regarding hazardous conditions that could foreseeably cause injury.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..raw_text: Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass. 372, 378–79 (1980).
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..proposition: Defendant breached its duty of care by negligently stacking heavy boxes of merchandise in an unsafe and unstable manner on upper store shelves without adequate restraints or precautions, thereby creating an unreasonable risk of harm to invitees.
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns Boston Edison’s alleged negligent design, selection, construction, and maintenance of a concrete streetlight pole and the duty to design it to accommodate foreseeable vehicular impacts. It does not involve a defendant stacking heavy boxes of merchandise, store shelving practices, or premises liability based on how merchandise is stored for invitees. The duty and breach analysis here is about product/design negligence for utility poles in a public streetscape, not about negligent stacking of goods in a store, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The complaints alleged against Edison that it had negligently designed, selected, constructed, and maintained the pole at Lexington Center… the gravamen of the plaintiffs’ case, as it appeared at trial, was that Edison had failed through negligence to design a pole that was accommodated reasonably to foreseeable vehicular impacts so as to avoid pedestrian injuries, and that the continued use of the pole created an unreasonable risk of such injuries.”

Ravo v. James W. Edwards, Inc., 6 Mass..raw_text: Ravo v. James W. Edwards, Inc., 6 Mass. App. Ct. 929 (1978).
Ravo v. James W. Edwards, Inc., 6 Mass..proposition: Defendant further failed to inspect the shelving and merchandise adequately and to address the dangerous condition, despite the foreseeability that a slight disturbance to the shelving, such as a customer bumping a shelf with a cart, could lead to the collapse of unsecured items.
Ravo v. James W. Edwards, Inc., 6 Mass..case_name: Babco Industries, Inc. v. New England Merchants National Bank
Ravo v. James W. Edwards, Inc., 6 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion deals entirely with statutes of limitations, characterizing claims as tort or contract, and the applicability of G.L. c. 93A and related limitations periods. It does not address premises liability, inspection of shelving or merchandise, foreseeability of collapse from customer contact, or any duty to remedy a dangerous condition. The cited case therefore provides no support for the proposition about a defendant’s failure to inspect shelving and prevent foreseeable collapse of unsecured items.
Ravo v. James W. Edwards, Inc., 6 Mass..relevant_excerpt: 1. A motion to dismiss under Mass.R.Civ.P. 12(b)(6)... lies against a complaint which shows on its face that the statute of limitations has run prior to the date the action was commenced... 2. Counts I and VII clearly sounded in tort and were thus barred by the two-year statute of limitations found in G. L. c. 260, § 2A... 3. Accepting the plaintiffs’ characterization of counts II, III and IV as alleging in "essence ... that the defendants, as controlling parties, owed a fiduciary duty..." we agree... that the alleged breaches of that duty... sounded in tort rather than in contract.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to warn against the latent danger posed by the improperly stacked boxes, but failed to provide any such warning.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns premises liability for a slip-and-fall on ice and abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction; it does not involve improperly stacked boxes or a latent defect of that nature. While it discusses a general duty to warn of non-obvious dangers in the abstract, there is no specific holding that a defendant owed a duty to warn about improperly stacked boxes, nor any facts about boxes at all. Using this case to support that specific proposition would be inaccurate and out of context.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises ‘in a reasonably safe condition….’ This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known.” (Papadopoulos, 457 Mass. at 371–72).

Scott v. Garfield, 454 Mass. 790 (2009)..proposition: As a direct and proximate result of this negligence, Plaintiff suffered the injuries and damages described herein.
Scott v. Garfield, 454 Mass. 790 (2009)..support_reasoning: The proposition is a generic causation allegation that the plaintiff’s injuries and damages were the direct and proximate result of the defendant’s negligence. Scott v. Garfield does involve personal injury caused by a defective porch railing and upholds a damages award, but it does not articulate or analyze any specific rule about pleading or proving that injuries were the ‘direct and proximate result’ of negligence. The opinion instead focuses on implied warranty of habitability, status of lawful visitors, spoliation, and evidentiary issues, so it does not serve as authority for the particular causation-pleading proposition quoted.
Scott v. Garfield, 454 Mass. 790 (2009)..relevant_excerpt: “Turning to the issues in this case, there was no error in the denial of the defendants’ motions for a directed verdict and for judgment notwithstanding the verdict. Based on the evidence, the jury reasonably could have found that the condition of the porch railing did not comply with the minimum standards required by the building and sanitary codes, in breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and that Scott suffered injuries as a result when the defective railing gave way.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s negligence constitutes a breach of its obligations under Massachusetts premises liability law.
